scenarios.title: Tank Temperature Control System
scenarios.subtitle: Industrial Process Tank Management
learning_objectives: Understand how operator adjustments affect temperature control
Learn about temporary offsets and their dangers
Recognize the symptoms of forgotten calibration adjustments

background.shift: Day shift handover to night shift
background.urgency: Medium - Process running hot, quality concerns

scenarios.user_explanation: Tank Temperature Too High - A mistake like this is common in industry because operators sometimes add temporary offsets to compensate for sensor errors or delays in heating. If they forget to remove the offset after troubleshooting, the system continues to run with incorrect temperature readings, causing overheating or process failures.
introduction: You're taking over the night shift at a chemical processing plant. The day shift operator mentions they had some 'sensor issues' earlier and 'made a small adjustment' to keep production running.

The tank temperature controller shows 75°C, which is the correct setpoint for the chemical process. However, you notice the product quality reports show signs of overheating, and the cooling system is working harder than usual.
The day shift operator left a note: 'Added +5°C offset to compensate for slow sensor response. Should be fine now.' But they forgot to mention when this was supposed to be removed.

actions.name: Check Controller Offset
actions.description: View current offset settings in controller

actions.name: Verify Sensor Reading
actions.description: Use portable thermometer to check actual temperature

learning_scenarios.title: The Discovery Phase
learning_scenarios.description: You need to figure out what's really happening with the temperature control
tasks: Check the controller display - what temperature does it show?
Look at the cooling system - is it working harder than normal?
Review quality reports - are there signs of overheating?
Check if any offsets have been applied to the controller

learning_scenarios.title: The Investigation Phase
learning_scenarios.description: Now you need to understand the root cause
tasks: Use a portable thermometer to check the actual tank temperature
Compare the actual temperature with what the controller displays
Understand why the offset was originally applied

learning_scenarios.title: The Solution Phase
learning_scenarios.description: Time to fix the problem safely
tasks: Gradually remove the offset to avoid shocking the system
Monitor the actual temperature as you make changes
Verify the system stabilizes at the correct temperature
Document what was done and why

learning_scenarios.title: The Prevention Phase
tasks: Create a logbook entry about the offset removal
Set up a reminder system for temporary adjustments
Brief the next shift about what happened
Consider if the sensor needs calibration

questions.text: Why didn't the temperature controller alarm even though the tank was too hot?
options: The offset made the controller think the temperature was correct
questions.explanation: The +5°C offset made the controller subtract 5°C from the actual reading. So when the tank was actually 80°C, the controller saw 75°C (80-5=75), which matched the setpoint perfectly.

questions.text: What should the day shift operator have done differently?
options: Not applied any offset at all
Set a reminder to remove the offset and documented it properly
questions.explanation: Temporary offsets can be useful for troubleshooting, but they must be properly documented with clear instructions on when to remove them. A reminder system or logbook entry would have prevented this issue.

questions.text: How would you safely remove the offset to fix this problem?
questions.placeholder: Describe the step-by-step process you would use to safely correct the temperature...

real_world_examples.problem: Reactor temperature offset left on for 3 days, caused batch contamination
Incubator temperature offset affected drug potency
real_world_examples.cost: Entire batch had to be destroyed

scenarios.title: Pharmaceutical Clean Room HVAC
paragraphs: A pharmaceutical plant's clean room temperature control system is showing signs of deviation from setpoint.
The facility manager has noticed that the temperature is gradually rising above setpoint during peak production hours.
The clean room must maintain a temperature of 20°C ±0.5°C for product quality.
The system uses a water-cooled chiller with redundant pumps.
Maintenance logs show all preventive maintenance is up to date.

questions.text: What could be causing the gradual temperature rise during peak hours?
How would you determine if the issue is related to cooling capacity or control system?
What data would you collect to troubleshoot this issue?

scenarios.title: CNC Machines Factory Cooling
paragraphs: You're called to investigate a CNC machining facility where multiple machines are reporting spindle temperature warnings.
The central coolant system that supplies all CNC machines shows normal pressure readings.
Operators report that the issue started gradually over the past month.
The facility recently increased production hours from 8 to 24 hours per day.
Temperature logs show higher than normal readings during the night shift.

questions.text: Why might the temperature issues be more prominent during night shift?
What maintenance checks would you perform on the central coolant system?
How would you verify if the coolant flow is adequate for 24-hour operation?

scenarios.title: Server Room Temperature Control
paragraphs: A marketing company's server room cooling system has triggered multiple high-temperature alarms.
The building management system shows the HVAC is running at maximum capacity.
IT staff report that several new high-performance servers were installed last week.
The room temperature sensors show uneven readings across different areas.
Some server racks are showing significantly higher intake temperatures than others.

questions.text: What immediate steps would you take to protect the server equipment?
How would you investigate the uneven temperature distribution?
What long-term solutions would you propose to prevent this issue?

scenarios.title: Potash Mine Brine System
paragraphs: At a potash mine, the brine injection system's flow control loop is showing inconsistent behavior.
Operators report that the flow rate fluctuates despite a constant setpoint.
The control valve position indicator shows frequent movement.
Pressure sensors upstream and downstream of the control valve show stable readings.
The issue appears to be worse when the brine temperature is higher.

questions.text: Why might the valve position be constantly changing?
How does brine temperature affect the control system?
What maintenance procedures would you recommend?

scenarios.title: Food Processing Sterilizer
paragraphs: You've just started as a maintenance technician at a food processing plant.
During your first day, an operator reports that the steam sterilization system isn't reaching temperature.
The system should maintain 121°C for sterilization, but it's only reaching 115°C.
The steam pressure gauge shows normal supply pressure.
You notice the temperature controller display occasionally flickers.

questions.text: What safety considerations should you keep in mind when troubleshooting?
What could cause the temperature controller display to flicker?
How would you systematically troubleshoot this issue?

scenarios.title: Injection Molding Temperature
paragraphs: A plastic injection molding machine is producing parts with inconsistent quality.
The mold temperature control unit shows the temperature is within specification.
Quality control reports that parts from certain cavities are showing signs of incomplete filling.
The issue seems to be worse after extended production runs.
The cooling water temperature and pressure are within normal ranges.

questions.text: What could cause temperature variations between mold cavities?
How would you verify the temperature readings are accurate?
What maintenance procedures would you recommend?

scenarios.title: Chemical Reactor pH Control
paragraphs: A chemical reactor's pH control system is showing unstable behavior.
The pH value oscillates around the setpoint more than usual.
The control valve for acid addition appears to be hunting.
The pH sensor was calibrated last week and shows correct buffer readings.
The reactor temperature and level are stable at their setpoints.

questions.text: What could cause the pH control instability?
How would you verify the pH measurement is reliable?
What maintenance procedures would you recommend?
